DOCNAME: CASE OF DMD GROUP, A.S., v. SLOVAKIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Non-pecuniary damage - award;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed
JUDGES: Giovanni Bonello;Ján Šikuta;Lech Garlicki;Mihai Poalelungi;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant company was established in DATE and has its seat in GPE .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant company commenced proceedings against CARDINAL major companies , seeking the enforcement of financial claims against the companies through seizure of their shares and transfer of title to the shares to the applicant company .

CARDINAL . The companies in question had been involved in arms production and had gone through a restructuring that resulted in a large number of job losses and a high rate of unemployment in the region . The relevant events therefore received media attention .

CARDINAL . The judicial enforcement officer ( súdny exekútor ) , PERSON , who had been involved in the enforcement of the claims in issue , was charged with abuse of authority . A. was eventually acquitted of that charge by GPE ORG ( ORG súd ) on DATE . Criminal proceedings were also brought against other individuals .
CARDINAL . Further details concerning the background can be found in the ORG 's judgment of DATE in the case of GPE v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant company petitioned ORG to enforce a claim for payment of an amount equivalent to MONEY ( ORG ) against PERSON , a private joint - stock company . A. subsequently sought judicial authorisation of the enforcement .
CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG , C. , sitting as a single judge , authorised PERSON to carry out the enforcement proceedings against B.

CARDINAL . NORP In the course of the enforcement proceedings , A. seized B. 's movable property and certain shares relating to PERSON attempted to sell the seized property at CARDINAL public auctions . As the auctions failed , the shares and movable property were transferred to the applicant company at PERCENT of their officially estimated value .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant company requested that the enforcement proceedings be ended , as its claim had been satisfied by the above - mentioned award of property .

CARDINAL . In a decision ( uznesenie ) of DATE , NORP , the newly appointed President of the ORG sitting as a single judge , ruled that the enforcement of the applicant company 's claim by means of selling the shares was improper ( neprípustná ) . At the same time , judge NORP discontinued the enforcement proceedings .

Judge NORP observed that the shares had been sold by way of a procedure that applied to movable property . However , as shares were not deemed to be movable property , a different procedure requiring special authorisation should have been used .
The CARDINAL - page decision was not subject to appeal .
CARDINAL . The distribution of cases and organisation of work at ORG is regulated by a work schedule ( rozvrh práce ) .

CARDINAL . The work schedule for ORG in DATE was drawn up in DATE by the then President of ORG , judge C. According to this work schedule , all enforcement proceedings – including the proceedings for the enforcement of the applicant company 's claim – were assigned to ORG Ninth Section , which was presided over by judge C. The work schedule provided that judge C. and judge NORP , who was at that time with ORG Seventh Section , were to substitute for each other if necessary .
A copy of the work schedule was sent to ORG for information on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE judge NORP was appointed as President of ORG . He occupied that position until DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE judge NORP issued an amendment to the work schedule . With effect from CARDINAL March CARDINAL , new enforcement proceedings were to be distributed evenly among CARDINAL different sections of the court , including the Seventh Section . Enforcement proceedings that had originally been assigned to ORG were also to be reassigned and distributed evenly among the CARDINAL designated sections . The amendment was worded in general terms without identifying any specific proceedings .
A copy of the amended work schedule was sent to ORG for information on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE judge NORP , in his capacity as President of ORG , issued a decree ( opatrenie ) reassigning the proceedings for the enforcement of the applicant company 's claim to himself .
In the CARDINAL - page decree , reference was made to section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL ) of ORG no . CARDINAL Coll . , as amended ) ( “ the Rules ” ) .

The decree formally stated that the reason for the reassignment was “ a change in the work schedule ” and that the reassignment was made “ in accordance with the system of substitution of judges fixed in the work schedule and for the purpose of ensuring the proper functioning of the court ” .

CARDINAL . In the period DATE and DATE , a total number of CARDINAL cases were reassigned from ORG . Of the total , CARDINAL cases were reassigned to judge D 's section and CARDINAL , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE and CARDINAL cases were reassigned to the remaining six Sections of the ORG respectively .

CARDINAL . Further amendments to ORG work schedule were issued by judge NORP throughout DATE , taking effect on DATE , DATE , CARDINAL DATE and DATE . They were all notified to ORG . Under these amendments , judge NORP was in charge of CARDINAL in CARDINAL enforcement proceedings and also continued to stand in for judge PERSON ( on a mutual basis ) .
CARDINAL . The applicant company lodged a complaint under LAW with ORG ( Ústavný súd ) .

It contended , inter alia , that its right to a hearing by a tribunal established by law had been violated by judge NORP 's assignation of the case to himself . The applicant company pointed to the fact that the case had been decided by judge NORP on DATE that it was reassigned to him . It also alleged that there had been frequent modifications to the work schedule of ORG in DATE which had rendered the process of assignment and reassignment of cases uncontrollable , thus leaving room for arbitrariness .
The applicant company also challenged the above - mentioned ruling declaring the enforcement proceedings improper .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared the part of the applicant company 's complaint concerning the reassignment of the case to judge NORP admissible under LAW . At the same time , it declared the remaining part of the complaint concerning the ruling on the merits inadmissible as manifestly ill - founded .
CARDINAL . In a judgment ( nález ) of CARDINAL DATE , ORG held , by CARDINAL majority , that there had been no violation of the applicant company 's rights under LAW .
CARDINAL . Having received extensive documentary evidence and having held a public hearing , the Constitutional Court established , inter alia , the facts summarised in paragraph CARDINAL above .

ORG found that the evidence available indicated that judge NORP had made the impugned decree of CARDINAL DATE in the context of modifications to the court 's work schedule for DATE , in the interests of an equal distribution of cases concerning enforcement proceedings , and in accordance with section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the Rules .

The court further held that the fact that judge NORP decided the case on DATE that he had given the above - mentioned decree did not , as such , affect the legal framework within which the change in judges had been effected .
ORG concluded that the applicant company had not sufficiently substantiated its allegation that the case had been assigned to judge NORP in an unjustified manner .

CARDINAL . The judge in the minority gave a dissenting opinion . He pointed to the fact that the work schedule of ORG had been modified several times in the course of DATE without any acceptable explanation . There was no indication that an objective and transparent method for the reassignment of cases had been established and applied . Moreover , during the relevant period no similar steps had been taken at ORG to redistribute cases in differing categories despite the far heavier case load in those other categories .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that no one may be deprived of his or her lawfully appointed judge ( zákonný sudca ) . The jurisdiction of a court in a particular matter is to be established by law .

CARDINAL . According to ORG , the right “ not to be deprived of his or her lawfully appointed judge ” pursuant to LAW is vested in each party to the proceedings ( as opposed to the judge ) ( decision of DATE in case no . II . ÚS CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG held in its judgment of CARDINAL DATE in case no . ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL that the right “ not to be deprived of his or her lawfully appointed judge ” attaches to the person of the judge and not to a court . A ' lawfully appointed ' judge is one who , fulfilling the statutory requirements for being a judge , has been assigned to a case under the work schedule of the court concerned .

CARDINAL . ORG has also held ( by a decision of DATE in case no . II . ÚS CARDINAL ) that the right of a person “ not to be deprived of his or her lawfully appointed judge ” can not be interpreted in so broad a manner as to pertain to a specific , individual judge .

The purpose of this constitutional right is therefore satisfied if an individual 's rights are decided upon by a judge who has been duly appointed to a court which has jurisdiction ratione loci and ratione materiae and is at the appropriate level of jurisdiction .

CARDINAL . In reviewing the additional constituent elements of the notion of a “ lawfully appointed judge ” under LAW , ORG held that it is not only statutory provisions , in particular those of ORG , that are of relevance but above all the provisions of the LAW , chiefly LAW , which provides that everyone may claim his or her rights by way of a procedure established by law before an independent and impartial court ( judgment of DATE in case no . III . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG has also held ( in its judgments in cases nos . II . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL , II . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL and II . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) that , in principle , a “ lawfully appointed judge ” is the judge assigned to a specific case under the work schedule of the court concerned . However , if there are circumstances justifying the reassignment of the case or of the entire agenda to a different judge for the reasons envisaged in sections CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) of the Rules , any newly assigned judge becomes a lawfully appointed judge . Such circumstances comprise , for example , the long - term absence of a judge , significant differences in workload among judges , or sudden events preventing a judge from taking specific steps in the proceedings .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE in case no . II . ÚS CARDINAL , ORG held that a president of a court must not use his discretion , contrary to the law , to take a case away from a lawfully appointed judge and assign it to another judge in order to accommodate one of the parties without providing a precise ground of justification for the reassignment .
CARDINAL . The Rules were issued by the Minister of ORG . As then in force , they defined the internal rules of ORG and the discharge of tasks by those courts .
Section CARDINAL of the Rules governed courts ' work schedules , that is to say the distribution of cases among court divisions and judges .

CARDINAL . Pursuant to paragraph CARDINAL of section CARDINAL , the distribution of work at courts was to be determined in a work schedule for a whole calendar year . The schedule of work was also to provide for the substitution of judges .

CARDINAL . Under paragraph CARDINAL , where a judge was absent for a long period or where there were substantial differences in the workload of judges at the same court , the President of the court was given power to decide that a certain amount of work be transferred to a different division of the court .

CARDINAL . Paragraph CARDINAL provided that , where a sudden event prevented a judge from carrying out individual acts in a case , the court 's president might charge a different judge to take the action required .

CARDINAL . Under paragraph CARDINAL , a court 's president was to take the measures indicated in paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL in accordance with the rules concerning the replacement of judges as defined in the work schedule , unless a different action was required with a view to ensuring the proper functioning of the court .
CARDINAL . No further statutory rules on the status and creation of courts ' work schedules existed at the relevant time .

CARDINAL . At the relevant time , the ORG administration of the judiciary was governed by PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ORG . , as amended . Pursuant to section CARDINAL of the PERSON , the bodies charged with the ORG administration of the judiciary were ORG and the Presidents and Vice - presidents of the courts .
CARDINAL . The ORG administration of ORG was carried out by ORG directly or through the Presidents of those courts ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) .
